Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of energy from a supernova explosion is expelled as neutrinos?
Options: A. 1, B. 90, C. 99, D. 10
Correct Option: C

Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,

consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A supernova is defined as _____.
Options: A. Meteor, B. Satellite crash, C. Planet explosion, D. Death of a star
Correct Option: D

Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second

every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size

Options: A. 1987, B. 1999, C. 1978, D. 1969

This question is about identifying the last supernova that sent detectable neutrinos to Earth, which is closely related to the ground truth MCQ about the last observable supernova. The correct option in Question 7, "The supernova in the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud," corresponds to the year 1987 mentioned in the ground truth MCQ. 

Although the questions are not identical, they share a similar intent and content, making Question 7 the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The three indices of the fraud triangle are pressure, opportunity and _____.
Options: A. Critical thinking, B. Rationalization, C. Justification, D. Validation
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the estimated total amount of money lost to fraud worldwide in 2013? Options: A. 3.5 trillion dollars, B. 3.7 trillion dollars, C. 4.2 trillion dollars, D. 5.1 trillion dollars Correct Option: B
Question 2: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what are the three conditions that make fraud likely, as described by the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Pressure, opportunity, and rationalization, B. Pressure, opportunity, and greed, C. Opportunity, rationalization, and entitlement, D. Pressure, rationalization, and greed Correct Option: A
Question 3: **Application**: A company is facing financial difficulties and is considering cutting costs by reducing employee benefits. However, this could lead to increased employee stress and pressure to engage in fraudulent activities. How might the company mitigate this risk? Options: A. By increasing employee benefits to reduce stress, B. By implementing a whistleblower policy to encourage reporting of suspicious activity, C. By hiring a new auditor to review financial statements, D. By reducing employee benefits and increasing surveillance Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis**: The transcript mentions several examples of fraud, including employees fudging time sheets and expense reports. What common thread might link these examples? Options: A. All of the perpetrators were high-level executives, B. All of the perpetrators were motivated by greed, C. All of the perpetrators were able to rationalize their actions, D. All of the perpetrators were underpaid and overworked Correct Option: C
Question 5: **Synthesis**: The transcript discusses the impact of fraud on individuals and organizations. What might be a potential solution to prevent or mitigate the effects of fraud? Options: A. Implementing stricter regulations and laws, B. Increasing transparency and accountability, C. Providing education and training on ethics and compliance, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: **Evaluation**: The transcript mentions several high-profile cases of fraud, including the Parmalat scandal and the Bernie Madoff Ponzi scheme. What might be a common factor in these cases? Options: A. All of the perpetrators were charismatic leaders, B. All of the perpetrators were motivated by greed, C. All of the perpetrators were able to rationalize their actions, D. All of the cases involved a lack of oversight and regulation Correct Option: D
Question 7: **Knowledge**: Who is the criminologist who developed the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Donald Cressey, B. Bernie Madoff, C. Rita Crundwell, D. Joseph Wells Correct Option: A
Question 8: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what is the role of rationalization in the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Rationalization is the motivation for committing fraud, B. Rationalization is the opportunity for committing fraud, C. Rationalization is the justification for committing fraud, D. Rationalization is the pressure to commit fraud Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: A non-profit organization is considering hiring a new employee who has a history of financial difficulties. How might the organization mitigate the risk of hiring someone who might engage in fraudulent activities? Options: A. By conducting a thorough background check, B. By requiring the employee to sign a confidentiality agreement, C. By implementing a whistleblower policy, D. By providing additional training on ethics and compliance Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Evaluation**: The transcript mentions several examples of fraud that affected real people, including employees who lost their jobs and customers who were overcharged. What might be a common theme in these examples? Options: A. All of the victims were wealthy individuals, B. All of the victims were innocent bystanders, C. All of the victims were affected by a lack of oversight and regulation, D. All of the victims were motivated by greed Correct Option: C
Question 11: **Knowledge**: What is the name of the Italian dairy food giant that went bankrupt after being found to have fabricated a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements? Options: A. Parmalat, B. Nestle, C. Danone, D. General Mills Correct Option: A
Question 12: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what was the role of Rita Crundwell in the city of Dixon, Illinois, and how was she able to embezzle over 53 million dollars? Options: A. Rita Crundwell was the city's mayor and was able to embezzle funds by manipulating the city's budget, B. Rita Crundwell was the city's comptroller and was able to embezzle funds by diverting money to a personal account, C. Rita Crundwell was a city council member and was able to embezzle funds by approving fraudulent invoices, D. Rita Crundwell was a private citizen and was able to embezzle funds by writing bad checks Correct Option: B
Question 13: **Application**: A company is considering implementing a new accounting system to reduce the risk of fraud. What features should the new accounting system include? Options: A. Real-time transaction tracking and alerts for suspicious activity, B. Manual entry of transactions and infrequent audits, C. Limited access to financial data and secure password protection, D. No internal controls or oversight Correct Option: A
Question 14: **Synthesis**: The transcript discusses the impact of fraud on individuals and organizations. What might be a potential long-term consequence of fraud on a company's reputation and financial stability? Options: A. Short-term financial losses and reputational damage, B. Long-term financial stability and increased reputation, C. No impact on the company's reputation or financial stability, D. The company may be able to recover from the fraud and emerge stronger Correct Option: A
Question 15: **Evaluation**: The transcript mentions several high-profile cases of fraud, including the Bernie Madoff Ponzi scheme. What might be a common factor in these cases that contributed to their success? Options: A. Charismatic leaders who were able to build trust with their victims, B. Complex financial transactions and lack of oversight, C. Low-risk investment opportunities with high returns, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 8: Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what is the role of rationalization in the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Rationalization is the motivation for committing fraud, B. Rationalization is the opportunity for committing fraud, C. Rationalization is the justification for committing fraud, D. Rationalization is the pressure to commit fraud Correct Option: C

However, an even more similar question is:

**Question 2: Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what are the three conditions that make fraud likely, as described by the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Pressure, opportunity, and rationalization, B. Pressure, opportunity, and greed, C. Opportunity, rationalization, and entitlement, D. Pressure, rationalization, and greed Correct Option: A

This question directly asks about the three indices of the fraud triangle, which is the same as the ground truth MCQ.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **2**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fraud is a $_____ problem.
Options: A. 2.5 billion, B. 3.7 trillion, C. 100 billion, D. 10 trillion
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work

by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people

somewhere is left holding the bill.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Rita Crundwell embezzled $______ from the City of Dixon.
Options: A. 40 million, B. 53 million, C. 5 million, D. 10 million
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the estimated total amount of money lost to fraud worldwide in 2013? Options: A. 3.5 trillion dollars, B. 3.7 trillion dollars, C. 4.2 trillion dollars, D. 5.1 trillion dollars Correct Option: B
Question 2: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what are the three conditions that make fraud likely, as described by the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Pressure, opportunity, and rationalization, B. Pressure, opportunity, and greed, C. Opportunity, rationalization, and entitlement, D. Pressure, rationalization, and greed Correct Option: A
Question 3: **Application**: A company is facing financial difficulties and is considering cutting costs by reducing employee benefits. However, this could lead to increased employee stress and pressure to engage in fraudulent activities. How might the company mitigate this risk? Options: A. By increasing employee benefits to reduce stress, B. By implementing a whistleblower policy to encourage reporting of suspicious activity, C. By hiring a new auditor to review financial statements, D. By reducing employee benefits and increasing surveillance Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis**: The transcript mentions several examples of fraud, including employees fudging time sheets and expense reports. What common thread might link these examples? Options: A. All of the perpetrators were high-level executives, B. All of the perpetrators were motivated by greed, C. All of the perpetrators were able to rationalize their actions, D. All of the perpetrators were underpaid and overworked Correct Option: C
Question 5: **Synthesis**: The transcript discusses the impact of fraud on individuals and organizations. What might be a potential solution to prevent or mitigate the effects of fraud? Options: A. Implementing stricter regulations and laws, B. Increasing transparency and accountability, C. Providing education and training on ethics and compliance, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: **Evaluation**: The transcript mentions several high-profile cases of fraud, including the Parmalat scandal and the Bernie Madoff Ponzi scheme. What might be a common factor in these cases? Options: A. All of the perpetrators were charismatic leaders, B. All of the perpetrators were motivated by greed, C. All of the perpetrators were able to rationalize their actions, D. All of the cases involved a lack of oversight and regulation Correct Option: D
Question 7: **Knowledge**: Who is the criminologist who developed the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Donald Cressey, B. Bernie Madoff, C. Rita Crundwell, D. Joseph Wells Correct Option: A
Question 8: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what is the role of rationalization in the fraud triangle model? Options: A. Rationalization is the motivation for committing fraud, B. Rationalization is the opportunity for committing fraud, C. Rationalization is the justification for committing fraud, D. Rationalization is the pressure to commit fraud Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: A non-profit organization is considering hiring a new employee who has a history of financial difficulties. How might the organization mitigate the risk of hiring someone who might engage in fraudulent activities? Options: A. By conducting a thorough background check, B. By requiring the employee to sign a confidentiality agreement, C. By implementing a whistleblower policy, D. By providing additional training on ethics and compliance Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Evaluation**: The transcript mentions several examples of fraud that affected real people, including employees who lost their jobs and customers who were overcharged. What might be a common theme in these examples? Options: A. All of the victims were wealthy individuals, B. All of the victims were innocent bystanders, C. All of the victims were affected by a lack of oversight and regulation, D. All of the victims were motivated by greed Correct Option: C
Question 11: **Knowledge**: What is the name of the Italian dairy food giant that went bankrupt after being found to have fabricated a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements? Options: A. Parmalat, B. Nestle, C. Danone, D. General Mills Correct Option: A
Question 12: **Comprehension**: According to the transcript, what was the role of Rita Crundwell in the city of Dixon, Illinois, and how was she able to embezzle over 53 million dollars? Options: A. Rita Crundwell was the city's mayor and was able to embezzle funds by manipulating the city's budget, B. Rita Crundwell was the city's comptroller and was able to embezzle funds by diverting money to a personal account, C. Rita Crundwell was a city council member and was able to embezzle funds by approving fraudulent invoices, D. Rita Crundwell was a private citizen and was able to embezzle funds by writing bad checks Correct Option: B
Question 13: **Application**: A company is considering implementing a new accounting system to reduce the risk of fraud. What features should the new accounting system include? Options: A. Real-time transaction tracking and alerts for suspicious activity, B. Manual entry of transactions and infrequent audits, C. Limited access to financial data and secure password protection, D. No internal controls or oversight Correct Option: A
Question 14: **Synthesis**: The transcript discusses the impact of fraud on individuals and organizations. What might be a potential long-term consequence of fraud on a company's reputation and financial stability? Options: A. Short-term financial losses and reputational damage, B. Long-term financial stability and increased reputation, C. No impact on the company's reputation or financial stability, D. The company may be able to recover from the fraud and emerge stronger Correct Option: A
Question 15: **Evaluation**: The transcript mentions several high-profile cases of fraud, including the Bernie Madoff Ponzi scheme. What might be a common factor in these cases that contributed to their success? Options: A. Charismatic leaders who were able to build trust with their victims, B. Complex financial transactions and lack of oversight, C. Low-risk investment opportunities with high returns, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 12. 

This question is about Rita Crundwell's role in the city of Dixon, Illinois, and how she was able to embezzle over 53 million dollars. Although the question format is not identical to the ground truth MCQ, the content and intent are very similar, as both questions focus on Rita Crundwell's embezzlement. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 12.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Sometimes the effects of fraud are not obvious and are hard to untangle.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

However, an even closer match can be found in the options of **Question 14: Synthesis**, which mentions short-term financial losses and reputational damage as a potential consequence of fraud. This question also implies that the effects of fraud can be far-reaching and not immediately apparent.

But the closest match in terms of question intent and content is actually **Question 5: Synthesis**, which asks about potential solutions to prevent or mitigate the effects of fraud. While not directly addressing the ground truth MCQ, it implies that the effects of fraud can be complex and multifaceted, requiring a comprehensive approach to prevent or mitigate them.

Among the generated MCQs, **Question 14: Synthesis** is the closest match in terms of question content, but **Question 5: Synthesis** is the closest match in terms of question intent.

However, upon re-examining the generated MCQs, I found an even closer match: **None of the questions directly match the ground truth MCQ, but Question 14 is the closest in terms of content**.



Since it's the closest match in terms of content, I will provide the index of **Question 14**.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the acceleration due to gravity on Earth?
Options: A. -9.8 meters per second squared, B. -4.9 meters per second squared, C. -32 meters per second squared, D. -16 meters per second squared
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the maximum hang time for a person jumping on a flat surface, according to the transcript? Options: A. 0.5 seconds, B. 1 second, C. 1.5 seconds, D. 2 seconds Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what law related to the concept of hang time was discovered by Isaac Newton? Options: A. The law of friction, B. The law of inertia, C. The law of motion, D. The law of universal gravitation Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the gravitational acceleration on Earth, according to the transcript? Options: A. 8.87 meters per second squared, B. 9.8 meters per second squared, C. 10.9 meters per second squared, D. 11.9 meters per second squared Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the equation that models hang time, according to the transcript? Options: A. h = v0t + 0.5gt^2, B. h = v0t - 0.5gt^2, C. h = v0t + gt^2, D. h = v0t - gt^2 Correct Option: A
Question 5: According to the transcript, if Michael Jordan jumps on the moon, how long will he be able to stay in the air? Options: A. Less than 0.5 seconds, B. 0.5 seconds, C. 1 second, D. Over 5.5 seconds Correct Option: D
Question 6: What would happen if Michael Jordan jumped on Jupiter with the same force as he did on Earth? Options: A. He would be able to get more than a meter off the ground, B. He would be able to get half a meter off the ground, C. He would not be able to get off the ground, D. He would be able to get more than 2 meters off the ground Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, how can we use the equation that models hang time to determine the hang time of Michael Jordan's free throw dunk? Options: A. By plugging in the values for initial height, initial velocity, and gravitational acceleration, B. By graphing the equation on a coordinate grid, C. By solving for the X-intercepts of the parabola, D. By using a calculator to solve for the hang time Correct Option: C
Question 8: If the gravitational acceleration on Venus is 8.87 meters per second squared, and Michael Jordan jumps on Venus with the same force as he did on Earth, how long will he be able to stay in the air? Options: A. Less than 1 second, B. 1 second, C. 1.5 seconds, D. More than 1 second Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between the height of a falling object and the time spent in the air? Options: A. The height is directly proportional to the time spent in the air, B. The height is inversely proportional to the time spent in the air, C. The height is proportional to the square of the time spent in the air, D. The height is a quadratic function of the time spent in the air Correct Option: D
Question 10: If Michael Jordan were to play a game on a planet with a gravitational acceleration of 24.92 meters per second squared, how long would he be able to stay in the air after jumping from half court? Options: A. Less than 0.41 seconds, B. .41 seconds, C. 1 second, D. More than 1 second Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine the acceleration due to gravity on Earth. The options for Question 3 also match the content and format of the ground truth MCQ, with the correct answer being 9.8 meters per second squared.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model

at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical

and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us

when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which is a possible equation that could model the relationship between height and hang time for someone on Venus?
Options: A. h=8.87t^2-4.5t, B. h=-8.87t^2+4.5t, C. h=-4.44t^2+4.5t, D. h=4.44t^2-4.5t
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the maximum hang time for a person jumping on a flat surface, according to the transcript? Options: A. 0.5 seconds, B. 1 second, C. 1.5 seconds, D. 2 seconds Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what law related to the concept of hang time was discovered by Isaac Newton? Options: A. The law of friction, B. The law of inertia, C. The law of motion, D. The law of universal gravitation Correct Option: D
Question 3: What is the gravitational acceleration on Earth, according to the transcript? Options: A. 8.87 meters per second squared, B. 9.8 meters per second squared, C. 10.9 meters per second squared, D. 11.9 meters per second squared Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the equation that models hang time, according to the transcript? Options: A. h = v0t + 0.5gt^2, B. h = v0t - 0.5gt^2, C. h = v0t + gt^2, D. h = v0t - gt^2 Correct Option: A
Question 5: According to the transcript, if Michael Jordan jumps on the moon, how long will he be able to stay in the air? Options: A. Less than 0.5 seconds, B. 0.5 seconds, C. 1 second, D. Over 5.5 seconds Correct Option: D
Question 6: What would happen if Michael Jordan jumped on Jupiter with the same force as he did on Earth? Options: A. He would be able to get more than a meter off the ground, B. He would be able to get half a meter off the ground, C. He would not be able to get off the ground, D. He would be able to get more than 2 meters off the ground Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, how can we use the equation that models hang time to determine the hang time of Michael Jordan's free throw dunk? Options: A. By plugging in the values for initial height, initial velocity, and gravitational acceleration, B. By graphing the equation on a coordinate grid, C. By solving for the X-intercepts of the parabola, D. By using a calculator to solve for the hang time Correct Option: C
Question 8: If the gravitational acceleration on Venus is 8.87 meters per second squared, and Michael Jordan jumps on Venus with the same force as he did on Earth, how long will he be able to stay in the air? Options: A. Less than 1 second, B. 1 second, C. 1.5 seconds, D. More than 1 second Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between the height of a falling object and the time spent in the air? Options: A. The height is directly proportional to the time spent in the air, B. The height is inversely proportional to the time spent in the air, C. The height is proportional to the square of the time spent in the air, D. The height is a quadratic function of the time spent in the air Correct Option: D
Question 10: If Michael Jordan were to play a game on a planet with a gravitational acceleration of 24.92 meters per second squared, how long would he be able to stay in the air after jumping from half court? Options: A. Less than 0.41 seconds, B. .41 seconds, C. 1 second, D. More than 1 second Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What type of function is the relationship between height and hang time?
Options: A. Linear, B. Exponential, C. Quadratic, D. Increasing
Correct Option: C

Question 6: What would happen if Michael Jordan jumped on Jupiter with the same force as he did on Earth? Options: A. He would be able to get more than a meter off the ground, B. He would be able to get half a meter off the ground, C. He would not be able to get off the ground, D. He would be able to get more than 2 meters off the ground Correct Option: C

By plugging in the values for initial height, initial velocity, and gravitational acceleration, B. By graphing the equation on a coordinate grid, C. By solving for the X-intercepts of the parabola, D. By using a calculator to solve for the hang time Correct Option: C

Options: A. Less than 1 second, B. 1 second, C. 1.5 seconds, D. More than 1 second Correct Option: D
Question 9: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between the height of a falling object and the time spent in the air? Options: A. The height is directly proportional to the time spent in the air, B. The height is inversely proportional to the time spent in the air, C. The height is proportional to the square of the time spent in the air, D. The height is a quadratic function of the time spent in the air Correct Option: D
Question 10: If Michael Jordan were to play a game on a planet with a gravitational acceleration of 24.92 meters per second squared, how long would he be able to stay in the air after jumping from half court? Options: A. Less than 0.41 seconds, B. .41 seconds, C. 1 second, D. More than 1 second Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. .92=-4.9(0)^2+4.51(0), B. .92=-9.8(0)^2+4.51(0), C. 0=-4.9(.92)^2+4.51(.92), D. 0=-9.8(.92)^2+4.51(.92)
Correct Option: C

have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Gluten can be found in which type of grains?
Options: A. Wheat, B. Rye, C. Barley, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten? Options: A. A type of carbohydrate found in grains, B. An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, C. A type of fiber found in wheat, D. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following conditions is an inherited disease where eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage of the lining of the small intestine? Options: A. Wheat allergy, B. Celiac disease, C. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity, D. Fructan intolerance Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. A gluten-free diet, B. Medication to reduce inflammation, C. Surgery to remove the small intestine, D. A combination of a gluten-free diet and medication Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the name given to the phenomenon where a person believes something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does? Options: A. The placebo effect, B. The nocebo effect, C. The gluten effect, D. The wheat effect Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the name given to the sensitivity to sugars found in wheat and other foods, called fructans? Options: A. Wheat intolerance, B. Fructan intolerance, C. Gluten sensitivity, D. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the primary cause of unpleasant symptoms in people with bowel problems due to fructan intolerance? Options: A. The fermentation of fructans by bacteria in the large intestine, B. The fermentation of fructans by bacteria in the large intestine, B. The absorption of fructans by the small intestine, C. The breakdown of fructans by enzymes, D. The elimination of fructans by the kidneys Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the estimated prevalence of celiac disease in the U.S.? Options: A. 1 in 100, B. 1 in 200, C. 1 in 500, D. 1 in 1000 Correct Option: B
Question 8: What are the primary symptoms of non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. Abdominal pain, B. Fatigue, C. Joint pain, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the most common condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins? Options: A. Celiac disease, B. Wheat allergy, C. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity, D. Fructan intolerance Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the name given to the condition where a person experiences anaphylaxis, a potentially life-threatening reaction, due to a wheat allergy? Options: A. Wheat intolerance, B. Wheat allergy, C. Celiac disease, D. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is the primary difference between celiac disease and non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, while non-celiac gluten sensitivity is not., B. Celiac disease causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine, while non-celiac gluten sensitivity does not., C. Celiac disease is caused by an immune reaction, while non-celiac gluten sensitivity is caused by a non-immune reaction., D. Celiac disease is treated with medication, while non-celiac gluten sensitivity is treated with a gluten-free diet. Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the role of the nocebo effect in non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. The nocebo effect is a common cause of non-celiac gluten sensitivity., B. The nocebo effect is a contributing factor to non-celiac gluten sensitivity., C. The nocebo effect is not a factor in non-celiac gluten sensitivity., D. The nocebo effect is a symptom of non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is the relationship between fructan intolerance and non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. Fructan intolerance is a type of non-celiac gluten sensitivity., B. Fructan intolerance is a different condition from non-celiac gluten sensitivity., C. Fructan intolerance is a cause of non-celiac gluten sensitivity., D. Fructan intolerance is a symptom of non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Correct Option: B
Question 14: What is the primary cause of unpleasant symptoms in people with bowel problems due to wheat allergy? Options: A. The immune system's allergic response to wheat proteins, B. The fermentation of fructans by bacteria in the large intestine, C. The absorption of fructans by the small intestine, D. The breakdown of fructans by enzymes Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is the treatment for wheat allergy? Options: A. A gluten-free diet, B. Medication to reduce inflammation, C. Avoidance of wheat and other allergenic foods, D. A combination of a gluten-free diet and medication Correct Option: C
Question 16: What is the estimated prevalence of wheat allergy in the U.S.? Options: A. 1 in 100, B. 1 in 200, C. 1 in 500, D. 1 in 1000 Correct Option: B
Question 17: What is the primary symptom of celiac disease? Options: A. Abdominal pain, B. Fatigue, C. Joint pain, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 18: What is the name given to the sensitivity to gluten in people who do not have celiac disease or wheat allergy? Options: A. Gluten intolerance, B. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity, C. Wheat intolerance, D. Fructan intolerance Correct Option: B
Question 19: What is the relationship between gluten and the small intestine? Options: A. Gluten is absorbed in the small intestine., B. Gluten is not absorbed in the small intestine., C. Gluten causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine., D. Gluten has no effect on the small intestine. Correct Option: C
Question 20: What is the treatment for non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. A gluten-free diet, B. Medication to reduce inflammation, C. Avoidance of wheat and other allergenic foods, D. A combination of a gluten-free diet and medication Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: An inherited disease in which eating gluten inflames and damages the lining of the small intenstine is called:
Options: A. A wheat allergy, B. Anaphylaxis, C. Celiac disease, D. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten? Options: A. A type of carbohydrate found in grains, B. An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin, C. A type of fiber found in wheat, D. A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following conditions is an inherited disease where eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage of the lining of the small intestine? Options: A. Wheat allergy, B. Celiac disease, C. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity, D. Fructan intolerance Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. A gluten-free diet, B. Medication to reduce inflammation, C. Surgery to remove the small intestine, D. A combination of a gluten-free diet and medication Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the name given to the phenomenon where a person believes something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does? Options: A. The placebo effect, B. The nocebo effect, C. The gluten effect, D. The wheat effect Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the name given to the sensitivity to sugars found in wheat and other foods, called fructans? Options: A. Wheat intolerance, B. Fructan intolerance, C. Gluten sensitivity, D. Non-celiac gluten sensitivity Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the primary cause of unpleasant symptoms in people with bowel problems due to fructan intolerance? Options: A. The fermentation of fructans by bacteria in the large intestine, B. The fermentation of fructans by bacteria in the large intestine, B. The absorption of fructans by the small intestine, C. The breakdown of fructans by enzymes, D. The elimination of fructans by the kidneys Correct Option: A

Question 8: What are the primary symptoms of non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. Abdominal pain, B. Fatigue, C. Joint pain, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Fructan intolerance is a symptom of non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Correct Option: B
